title: 107_hr2313
content: The Act titled "Crane Tithe Tax Act of 2001" repeals the taxation of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various tax provisions related to corporate income tax, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, and tax imposed on life insurance companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various tax provisions related to corporate income tax, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, tax imposed on life insurance companies, certain mutual insurance companies, other insurance companies, regulated investment companies, and real estate investment trusts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals tax provisions related to corporate income tax, alternative minimum tax, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, and taxes on certain financial institutions and insurance companies. SEC. 3 introduces a 10 percent income tax rate for individuals in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A 10 percent income tax is imposed on individuals based on earned income exceeding the exemption amount, which is $10,000 adjusted for inflation. The exemption amount for any taxable year is $10,000, adjusted annually for inflation based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The cost-of-living adjustment for any taxable year is based on the Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. The cost-of-living adjustment for the preceding calendar year exceeds the CPI for October of 2000. The CPI refers to the Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. Any increase not a multiple of $10 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Earned income is also considered for adjustments. The increase determined under this paragraph is rounded to the nearest multiple of $10 if not already a multiple of $10. Earned income includes wages, salaries, and other employee compensation. The term 'earned income' includes wages, salaries, net earnings from self-employment, and certain dividends from personal service corporations. The term 'earned income' for tax purposes includes wages, salaries, self-employment earnings, and specific dividends from personal service corporations. It does not encompass pension or annuity payments, or tips given at the discretion of the recipient. Exceptions to the definition of 'earned income' for tax purposes include pension or annuity payments and tips given at the discretion of the recipient. Fringe benefits included as earned income are valued at the employer's cost. Amnesty is granted for all prior tax liability before January 1, 2000, under the Internal Revenue Code. Exceptions include amounts paid before the enactment of the Act and taxes related to illegal activities. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF SPECIAL DEDUCTIONS, CREDITS, AND EXCLUSIONS FROM INCOME FOR INDIVIDUALS. Chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing specific exclusions, deductions, and credits related to individual income tax liability. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF ESTATE AND GIFT TAXES. Subtitle B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding estate, gift, and generation-skipping taxes is repealed. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATES. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years after enactment. Repeal of estate and gift taxes applies to estates of decedents dying after enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Committee on Ways and Means within 90 days of enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical and conforming changes to the Committee on Ways and Means within 90 days of the enactment of this Act.
